sec_questions: Does not depend on the method of measurement
Is more in SI system than in CGS system
Directly proportional to the fundamental units of mass, length and time

The SI base units are larger than their CGS counterparts. For example, 1 meter is equal to 100 centimeters, and 1 kilogram is equal to 1000 grams. This means that in the SI system, the base units inherently represent larger quantities compared to the CGS system. So, the magnitude of any physical quantity is more in SI system than in CGS system.
If the unit of length and force be increased four times, then the unit of energy is:

Let, the unit of Length \(=L\), and Unit of Force \(=F\).

Now, energy \((E)\) can be expressed in terms of length and force. 

\(E=F \cdot d\)

Where \(E=\) energy, \(F=\) force, \(d=\) distance (which is directly related to length)

Now, according to question, if both the units of length and force are increased four times:

The new unit of length \(=4 L\) and new unit of force becomes \(=4 F\)

Then new energy \(E^{\prime}=(4 F) \cdot(4 d)=16(F \cdot d)=16 E\)

So, the unit of energy \(\left(E^{\prime}\right)\) increases 16 times when both the unit of length and force are increased four times.

The tesla (T) is the unit of measurement for magnetic flux density or magnetic induction, which quantifies the strength of a magnetic field. One tesla is defined as the magnetic flux density resulting from a one newton per square meter (1 N/m2) force acting on a conductor carrying a current of one ampere, perpendicular to the magnetic field.
Which of the following is different from others by units?

Poisson's ratio is a dimensionless quantity. It's the ratio of the relative contraction strain (or transverse strain) to the relative extension strain (or axial strain), in the direction of the applied force. Since it's a ratio of similar quantities, it doesn't have any units.

Phrase difference unit - degree or radian

Mechanical equivalent unit - joules per calorie or calories per joule(depending on the convention)

Loudness of sound unit - decibels (dB)
If \(\mathrm L\) and \(\mathrm R\) are respectively the inductance and resistance, then the dimensions of \(\frac{\mathrm L}{\mathrm R}\) will be:
Cannot be represented in terms of \(\mathrm {[M],[L]}\) and \(\mathrm [T]\)

We know that,

Dimensional formula of \(\mathrm{L}=[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{~A}^{-2}]\)

Dimensional formula for \(\mathrm{R}=[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-3} \mathrm{~A}^{-2}]\) 

\( \frac{\mathrm L}{\mathrm R}=\frac{[\mathrm{M L^2}]}{\mathrm{[T^2 A^2]}} \times \frac{\mathrm{[T^2 A^2]}}{\mathrm{[M L^2]}}=[\mathrm{M}^0 \mathrm{~L}^0 \mathrm{~T}]\)

So, when \(\mathrm L\) and \(\mathrm R\) are respectively the inductance and resistance, then the dimensions of \(\frac{\mathrm L}{\mathrm R}\) will be \([\mathrm{M}^0 \mathrm{~L}^0 \mathrm{~T}]\).
The dimensional formula for impulse is same as the dimensional formula for:

The force acting on an object is given by \(F=m a\)

From the above equation, the unit of force becomes kilogram meter per second square and the dimensional formula for impulse is \(\left[M L T^{-1}\right]\).

Now, the momentum of an object is given by \(P=m v\)

From the above equation, the dimensional formula for momentum is \(\left[M L T^{-1}\right]\) which is the same as the dimensional formula for impulse.

The unit of the Planck's constant is \(=J \cdot s\)

So, its dimension is \(\left[M L^2 T^{-1}\right]\)

The angular momentum is given as:

\(L=m v r\)

\([L]=\left[M L^2 T^{-1}\right]\)

Planck's constant \([\mathrm{h}]=[\) Angular momentum \(]=\left[M L^2 T^{-1}\right]\)

So, Planck's constant has the dimensions (unit) of angular momentum.
Which one of the following quantities has dimensions different from the remaining three?
Product of voltage and charge per unit volume

Energy density \(=\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text {Volume }}=\frac{[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]}{[\mathrm{~L}^3]}=[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

Force per unit area \(=\frac{[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}]}{[\mathrm{~L}^2]}=[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

Product of the charge per unit volume and voltage

\(=\mathrm{Q} \frac{(\mathrm{IT}) \mathrm{V}}{\text { Volume }}=\frac{[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]}{[\mathrm{~L}^3]}=[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

Angular momentum per unit mass \(=\frac{[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}]}{[\mathrm{M}]}=[\mathrm{L}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}]\)

So, angular momentum per unit mass has dimensions different from the remaining three.
Which of the following quantities does not have Nm–2 as the unit?

Strain does not have Nm–2 as its unit. Strain is a dimensionless quantity because it represents the ratio of the change in length (or deformation) to the original length of the object. Since it's a ratio of lengths, it doesn't have any units.
Which of the options has two quantities that have different dimensions?

Coefficient of friction and Reynolds no. have no dimensions. So, their dimensions are same and can be represent as \(=\mathrm{[M^0L^0 {T}^0]}\)

Latent heat \(=\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text {Mass }}=\frac{[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]}{[\mathrm{M}]}=[\mathrm{L}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

Gravitational potential \(=\frac{G M}{r}=\frac{\text {Force }}{\text {Mass }} \times r=\frac{[\mathrm{M^1 L^1 T^{-2}}]}{[\mathrm M^1]} \times \mathrm {[L^1]=[L^2 T^{-2}]}\)

So, the dimensions of both are same.

Curie \(=\) frequency of light wave \(=[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{L}^{0} \mathrm{T}^{-1}]\)

So, the dimensions of both are same.

Planck's constant \(=[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}]\)

Torque \(=[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

So, the dimensions of both are not same.
The dimensions of \(\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\), where \(B\) is magentic field and \(\mu_0\) is the magnetic permiability of vaccum, is:

The quantity of \(\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\) is the energy density of magnetic field.

\(\Rightarrow\left[\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\right]=\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Volume }}\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\right] \frac{\text { Force } \times \text { displacement }}{(\text { length })^3}\)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\right]=\left[\frac{\left[M L T^{-2}\right][L]}{[L^3]}\right] \)

\(\Rightarrow\left[\frac{B^2}{2 \mu_0}\right]=[M L^{-1} T^{-2}]\)
________ is the international unit of measuring Energy.

Joule is the international unit of measuring Energy. It is part of the International System of Units (SI), which is the modern form of the metric system. 

The joule is defined as the amount of work done when a force of one newton is applied over a distance of one meter in the direction of the force. Mathematically, 1 joule \(=\) 1 newton \(\times \)1 meter.
Lux is unit of which physical quantity?
The lux is indeed the derived International System of Units (SI) unit of illumination, which measures the amount of luminous flux (light) incident on a surface per unit area.
What are the dimensions of gravitational potential?

The dimensional formula of the mass \(=[M]\)

The dimensional formula of the work done \([\mathrm{W}]=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

The dimensional formula of the gravitational potential is derived as,

\([U]=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M L^2 T^{-2}}\right]}{[\mathrm M]}=\left[\mathrm{M^0 L^2 T^{-2}}\right]\)

So, the dimensional formula of the gravitational potential is \(\left[\mathrm{M^0 L^2 T^{-2}}\right]\).
The unit of magnetic dipole moment is:

Magnetic dipole moments have dimensions of energy divided by magnetic flux density or current times area.

The magnetic dipole moment is given by:

\(\mu=\mathrm{N} \text { i A }\)

\(\mathrm{N}\) is the no. of turns which has no unit, \(\mathrm{A}\) is the area of the coil with unit square meter, and I is current in the coil with unit ampere. So the unit of \(\mu\) is the ampere-meter2.
What is the dimensional formula of strain?

The ratio of change in configuration to the original configuration is called strain. As the strain is the ratio of two like quantities, it has no units and no dimensions. Its dimension can be expressed as \([\mathrm{{M}^0 {L}^0 {T}^0}]\).
The unit Joule/coulomb is the same as:

The potential difference between two points in an electric field may be defined as the amount of work done in moving a unit positive charge from one point to the other against the electrostatic force i.e.,

Electric potential \((\mathrm{V})=\frac{\text { Work done (W) }}{\text { Charge }(\mathrm{q})}\)

We know that, SI unit of work done is joule and the SI unit of charge is the coulomb, then

\(1 \mathrm {V=\frac{J}{C}}\)

So, Joule/coulomb is the same as \(1 \mathrm{~V}\).
The unit of surface tension may be expressed as:

The property of liquid surfaces to shrink into the minimum surface area possible is known as surface tension.

Surface tension \(= \frac{\mathrm F}{\mathrm L} \) units \(=\mathrm{Nm}^{-1} \)

\(=(\mathrm N \mathrm{m}) / \mathrm{m}^2=\text { Joule } / \mathrm{m}^2\) = Joule metre-2
The dimension of \(\frac{\mathrm{h}}{\mathrm{e}}\) is the same as of (here \(h\) is Planck's constant and \(e\) is electronic charges):

Plancks constant \((\mathrm{h})\) has joule-seconds. dimensions are \(=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]\) electron charge (e) will have \(\mathrm{[TI]}\)

Dimension for \(\mathrm{{h} / {e}}\) will be \(=[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{I}^{-1}]\)

From the given options,

Dimension for magnetic moment \(=\left[\mathrm{L}^2 \mathrm{~A}\right]\)

Dimension for magnetic flux \(=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{I}^{-1}\right]\)

Dimension for electric flux \(=\left[\mathrm{ML}^3 \mathrm{~T}^{-3} \mathrm{I}^{-1}\right]\)

Dimension for electric field strength \(=\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-3} \mathrm{I}^{-1}\right]\)

Both magnetic flux and \(\mathrm{{h} / {e}}\) will have same dimensions.

Backlash error also called as play or lash (by mechanical engineers) is mostly encountered when we try to move the instrument back and forth rapidly i.e. when we are changing direction of motion of the instrument. Backlash error is present in Vernier calipers, screw gauge and Spherometer.

If energy of photon is \(\mathrm{E} \propto \mathrm{h}^{\mathrm{a}} \mathrm{c}^{\mathrm{b}} \lambda^{\mathrm{d}}\). Here, \(h=\) plank's constant, \(c=\) speed of light, \(\lambda=\) wavelength of photon. Then the values of \(a, b\) and \(d\) are:

\(\mathrm{E} \propto \mathrm{h}^{\mathrm{a}} \mathrm{c}^{\mathrm{b}} \lambda^{\mathrm{d}}\)

or \(\mathrm{E=k h^a c^b \lambda^d}\cdots (1)\)

Here

\({[\mathrm{E]=\left[M^{1} L^2 T^{-2}\right]}} \)

\({[\mathrm{h]=\left[M^{1} L^2 T^{-1}\right]}} \)

\({[\mathrm{C]=\left[L^{1} T^{-1}\right]} }\)

\({[\mathrm{\lambda]=\left[M^0 L^{1} T^{0}\right]}}\)

From these terms and equation (1)

Hence

\({\left[M^1 L^2 T^{-2}\right]= k\left[M^1 L^2 T^{-1}\right]^a \times \left[M^0 L^1 T^{-1}\right]^ b} \times \left[M^0 L^1 T^0\right]^d\)

On Compairing:

\( a=1, b=1,  d=-1\)
Which of the following pairs does not have similar dimensions?

Surface Tension \((T)=\frac{\text { Force }}{\text { Length }} \ldots\). (1)

Since, Force \(=\) Mass \(\times\) Acceleration

And, Acceleration \(=\frac{\text { velocity }}{\text { time }}=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-2}\right]\)

\(\therefore\) The dimensional formula of force \(=[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}] \ldots\) (2)

On substituting equation (2) in equation (1) we get,

Surface Tension \((T)=\frac{\text { Force }}{\text { Length }}\)

Or, \(\mathrm{T}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{L}^1\right]}=[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

Therefore, surface tension is dimensionally represented as \(\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

Tension is defined as the magnitude of force.

\(\therefore\) Demension of Tension \(=\) Dimension of Force

So, dimension of tension \(=[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}]\)

So the dimension of tension and surface tension is different.
What is an international (SI) unit of electric current?
Ampere is the international (SI) unit of electric current. It is defined as one coulomb per second, where a coulomb (symbol: C) is the unit of electric charge.

A small steel ball of radius \(r\) is allowed to fall under gravity through a column of a viscous liquid of coefficient of viscosity \(\eta\). After some time the velocity of the ball attains a constant value known as terminal velocity \(\mathrm{v}_{\mathrm{T}}\). The terminal velocity depends on the mass of the ball \(\mathrm{m}\),\(\eta\), \(\mathrm{r}\) and acceleration due to gravity \(\mathrm{g}\). Which of the following relations is dimensionally correct?

The dimension of terminal velocity \(v_T\) is,

\(\left[{V}_{{T}}\right]=\left[L T^{-1}\right]\cdots(1)\)

From the formula of drag force,

\( F_D=6 \pi\eta r v_T \)

\(\Rightarrow[\eta]=\frac{\left[F_D\right]}{\left[6 \pi r v_T\right]} \)

\(\Rightarrow[\eta]=\frac{\left[{MLT}^{-2}\right]}{[L]\left[L T^{-1}\right]}=\left[{ML}^{-1} {~T}^{-1}\right]\)

Taking option (A)

\(\frac{[\mathrm{mg}]}{[\eta r]}=\frac{\left[M L T^{-2}\right]}{\left[M L^{-1} T^{-1} \times L\right]}=\left[L T^{-1}\right]\)

From (1), this option matches the dimension of \({v}_{{T}}\).
To change units from one system to another
To check the consistency of a dimensional equation
To derive the relation between physical quantities in physical phenomena

Dimensional analysis is a fundamental aspect of measurement and is applied in real-life physics. We make use of dimensional analysis for three prominent reasons:

  • To check the consistency of a dimensional equation
  • To derive the relation between physical quantities in physical phenomena
  • To change units from one system to another
Which of the following units denotes the dimensions \(\mathrm{ML}^2 / \mathrm{Q}^2\), where \(\mathrm{Q}\) denotes the electric charge?

Weber \(=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{I}^{-1} =M L^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{Q}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1} \mathrm{Q}^{-1}\left(\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{QT}^{-1}\right)\)

Henry \(\mathrm{H}\) is \(\mathrm{SI}\) unit of inductance.

\( \mathrm{H}=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{I}^{-2}\) and \(\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{QT}^{-1} \)

So \(\mathrm{H}=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2} \mathrm{Q}^{-2} \mathrm{~T}^2=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{Q}^{-2}\)
In SI unit system, pascal is the unit of:
The force per unit area is called pressure. The SI unit of pressure is the pascal (Pa).
Which of the following is the dimension of power?

We know that,

Pressure \(P=\frac{W}{t}\)

Where, \(\mathrm{P}=\) power, \(\mathrm{W}=\) work done and \(t=\) time.

Now,

Dimensional formula of work \((\mathrm{W})=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

Dimensional formula of time \((t)=\left[T^1\right]\)

\(\mathrm{P=\frac{M L^2 T^{-2}}{T^1}=\frac{M L^2}{T^3}}\)

\(\therefore\) The dimensional formula of power \(\mathrm{P}\) is \(\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-3}\right]\).
Which of the following is not a physical quantity?

The Kilogram (kg) represents the unit of a physical quantity and not the physical quantity. The kilogram is a unit of measurement for the physical quantity of mass. It represents the base unit of mass in the SI system.
A force \(F\) is given by \(F=a t+b t^2\), where \(t\) is time. What are the dimensions of \(a\) and \(b\)?

\(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{at}+\mathrm{bt}^2\) where \(\mathrm{t}\) is time.

For this equation to be dimensionally correct, the each term in the right hand side should have the dimensions of \(\mathrm{F}\).

Dimensional formula of \(\mathrm{F}=\left[[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}]\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{aT}=\left[[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}]\right] \)

\(\Rightarrow \text { Dimension of } \mathrm{a} \text { is }\left[[\mathrm{MLT}^{-3}]\right]\)

And \(\Rightarrow \mathrm{bT}^2=\left[[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}]\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Dimension of \(\mathrm{b}\) is \(\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-4}\right]\)

So, the dimensions of \(a\) and \(b\) are \([M L T^{-3}]\) and \([M L T^{-4}]\).
The magnitude of the difference between the individual measurement and true value of the quantity is called:

The magnitude of the difference between the individual measurement and true value of the quantity is called absolute error.

The absolute error is calculated by taking the absolute value of the difference between the measured value and the true value. Mathematically, it is expressed as:

Absolute Error = Measured Value − True Value

This ensures that the error is always positive (or zero), regardless of whether the measured value is greater or less than the true value.
The velocity of a freely falling body depends on \(g^{p} h^{q}\), where \(g\) is acceleration due to gravity and \(h\) is the height. The values of \(p\) and \(q\) are:

Given:

\(v \propto g^{p} h^{q}\)

We know that:

\(v=\left[\mathrm{L} \mathrm{T}^{-1}\right]\)

\(g=\left[\mathrm{L} \mathrm{T}^{-2}\right]\)

\(h=[\mathrm{L}]\)

By substituting the dimension of each quantity and comparing the powers in both sides we get:

\({\left[\mathrm{L} \mathrm{T}^{-1}\right]=\left[\mathrm{L} \mathrm{T}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{p}}[\mathrm{L}]^{\mathrm{q}}} \)

\(\Rightarrow {\left[\mathrm{L} \mathrm{T}^{-1}\right]=\left[\mathrm{L}^{\mathrm{p}+\mathrm{q}} \mathrm{T}^{-2 \mathrm{p}}\right]}\)

On comparing the powers

\( p+q=1,-2 p=-1 \)

\(\therefore p=\frac{1}{2}, q=\frac{1}{2}\)
Which of the following pairs has the same dimensions?

Impulse is defined as the change in momentum.

Impulse I \(=\Delta \mathrm{p}=\mathrm{mv}-\mathrm{mu}\)

So, both Impulse and momentum have the same units/dimensions.
Which of the following physical quantity is dimensionless?

\(\text { Angle }(\theta)=\frac{\text { Length of arc }(l)}{\text { radius }(r)} = \theta=\frac{\left[M^{0} L T^{0}\right]}{\left[M^{0} L T^{0}\right]}=1\)

\(\therefore\) An angle is a dimensionless quantity.

\(\text { Strain }=\frac{\text { change in length }(\Delta l)}{\text { original length }(l)} =\frac{\left[M^{0} L T^{0}\right]}{\left[M^{0} L T^{0}\right]}=1\)

\(\therefore\) Strain is a dimensionless quantity.

\(\text { Specific gravity }(\rho)=\frac{\text { Density of the object }\left(\rho_{\text {object}}\right)}{\text { Density of water }\left(\rho_{\text {water}}\right)} =\frac{\left[M L^{3} T^{0}\right]}{\left[M L^{3} T^{0}\right]}=1\)

\(\therefore\) Specific gravity is a dimensionless quantity.
Find the dimensional formula for magnetic field \(\vec{B}\) from the given formula \(\vec{F}=q \vec{B}|\vec{v} \sin \theta|\).

Given:

\(\vec{F}=q \vec{B}|\vec{v} \sin \theta|\)

\([F]=\left[M L T^{-2}\right]\)

\([Q]=[A T]\)

\([V]=\left[L T^{-1}\right]\)

\(\operatorname{Sin} \theta\) = Dimensionless

\([B]=\frac{\mid F]}{\mid q][v]}\)

\(=\frac{\left[M L T^{-2}\right]}{\mid A T]\left[L T^{-1}\right]}\)

\(=\left[M L^{0} T^{-2} A^{-1}\right]\)

\(=\left[M T^{-2} A^{-1}\right]\)
Express the formula of gravitational constant in terms of mass, velocity, and wavelength?

We know that:

\(\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{G} \frac{M^{2}}{R^{2}}\)

Dimention of \(G=\left[M^{-1} L^{3} T^{-2}\right]\).....(1)

\(\Rightarrow G=\left[M^{-1} L^{3} T^{-2}\right] \)

Where, \(\text {Mass }=[\mathrm{M}]\),

\(\text {Velocity }=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right]\) and

\( \text {Wavelength }(\lambda)=[\mathrm{L}] \)

According to the question: we have to express the formula of gravitational constant in terms of mass, velocity, and wavelength.

So, 

\( G \propto M^{x}{V^{y}} \lambda^{z} \).....(2)

From (1).

\({\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1}\left. L^{3} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right] \propto\left[\mathrm{M}^{1}\right]^{\mathrm{x}}\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right]^{y}[\mathrm{~L}]\right.} \)

\({\Rightarrow \left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} L^{3} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right] \propto[\mathrm{M}]^{\mathrm{x}}[\mathrm{L}]^{y+z}[\mathrm{~T}]^{-y}}\)

On comparing the power of \(M, L{,} T\)

\(x=-1, y+z=3,-y=-2\)

Put these values in (2).

\( G \propto M^{-1} V^{2} \lambda^{1} \)

\(G \propto \frac{\left(V^{2} \lambda\right)}{M}\)

A physical quantity Q is found to depend on observables \(\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y}\) and \(\mathrm{z}\), obeying relation \(\mathrm{Q}=\frac{\mathrm{x}^{2 / 5} \mathrm{z}^{3}}{\mathrm{y}}\) The percentage error in the measurements of \(\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y}\) and \(\mathrm{z}\) are \(1 \%, 2 \%\) and \(4 \%\) respectively. What is percentage error in the quantity Q will be:

The given quantity \(Q=\frac{x^{3} y^{2}}{z}\)

Percentage error in \(\mathrm{Q} =\frac{\Delta \mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{Q}} \times 100=3 \frac{\Delta \mathrm{x}}{\mathrm{x}} \times 100+2 \frac{\Delta \mathrm{y}}{\mathrm{y}} \times 100+\frac{\Delta \mathrm{z}}{\mathrm{z}} \times 100\)

Percentage error in \(\mathrm{x}, \mathrm{y}\) and \(\mathrm{z}\) are \(1 \%, 2 \%\) and \(4 \%\) respectively.

Percentage error in \(\mathrm{Q}= \frac{\Delta \mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{Q}} \times 100=3 \frac{1}{100} \times 100+2 \frac{2}{100} \times 100+\frac{4}{100} \times 100\)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{\Delta \mathrm{Q}}{\mathrm{Q}} \times 100=3(1)+2(2)+1(4)\)

\(=11 \%\)
Measuring the quantity with more than one instrument
Taking large number of observations and then their mean

Random errors are statistical fluctuations (in either direction) in the measured data due to the precision limitations of the measurement device. Random errors can be evaluated through statistical analysis and can be reduced by averaging over a large number of observations (see standard error). These errors can be eliminated by taking large number of observations and then their mean.
If the fundamental quantities are energy \((E)\), velocity \((v)\) and force \((F)\), then what will the dimensions of mass?

We know that,

\( {[\mathrm{E}]=\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}} \)

\( {[{v}]=\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}} \)

\({[\mathrm{~F}]=\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}}\)

Let dimension of mass in \(\mathrm{E}\) is \(=\mathrm{x}\)

Let dimension of mass in \({v}\) is \(=\mathrm{y}\)

Let dimension of mass in \(\mathrm{F}\) is \(=\mathrm{z}\)

Then, \(\mathrm{M}=\mathrm{E}^{\mathrm{x}} {v}^{\mathrm{y}} \mathrm{F}^{\mathrm{z}}\)

\(\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{T}^{0}=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{x}}\left[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]^{\mathrm{y}}\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]^{\mathrm{z}}\)

\(\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{T}^{0}=\mathrm{M}^{\mathrm{x}+\mathrm{z}} \mathrm{L}^{2 \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{y}+\mathrm{z}} \mathrm{T}^{-2 \mathrm{x}-\mathrm{y}-2 \mathrm{z}}\)

\(\mathrm{x}+\mathrm{z}=1\cdots(i) \)

\(2 \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{y}+\mathrm{z}=0\cdots(ii) \)

\(2 \mathrm{x}+\mathrm{y}+2 \mathrm{z}=0\cdots(iii) \)

By equation (i), (ii) & (iii)

\( x=1 \), \( y=-2 \), \(z=0\)

So, \([\mathrm{M}]=\mathrm{E}{v}^{-2}\)
Which of the following units denotes the dimensions \(\frac{\mathrm{ML}^2 }{\mathrm{Q}^2}\), where \(\mathrm{Q}\) denotes the electric charge?

Henry is the unit of inductance (L). 

Inductance (L) \(=\frac{\text {Flux}(\phi)}{\text {Current}(I)}=\frac{\phi}{I}\)

Now,

Dimension of \(\phi=\left[ML^2 T^{-2} A^{-1}\right]\)

Dimension of \(I=[A]\)

\( L=\frac{\phi}{I}=\frac{\left[M L^2 T^{-2} A^{-1}\right]}{[A]}=\frac{\left[ML^2\right]}{\left[A^2 T^2\right]} \)

Charge \(=\text {Current}\times \text {time }\) or \({[Q]=[A][T]} \)

\(\Rightarrow L = \frac{\left[ML^2\right]}{\left[A^2 T^2\right]} =\frac{\left[ML^2\right]}{\left[Q^2\right]}\)
The dimensional formula of Planck's constant is:

Planck's constant is a physical constant that is the quantum of electromagnetic action. It relates the energy carried by a photon to its frequency by

\({E}={h v}\).

\( h=\frac{E}{v}\)

Where, \({E}=\) energy, \({v}=\) frequency and \({h}=\) Planck's constant.

Now,

Dimensional formula of energy \(({E})=\left[{ML}^2 {~T}^{-2}\right]\)

Dimensional formula of frequency \(({v})=\left[{T}^{-1}\right]\)

\( h=\frac{[M L^2 T^{-2}]}{[T^{-1}]} \)

\( \therefore{h}=[{ML}^2 {~T}^{-1}]\)
An Odometer is an instrument used to measure ________ in automobiles.

An odometer or odograph is a device used to measure the distance travelled by the vehicle.

An odometer is a device that is used for measuring the distance travelled by a vehicle. The odometer is usually situated in the vehicle's dashboard. The word "odometer" is derived from two Greek words meaning path and measure.
In a pendulum, the time period is measured by \(0.2 \%\) accuracy and length are measured by \(0.5 \%\) accuracy. Find the percentage accuracy in the value of \(\mathrm{g}\).

Time period formula using pendulum \(T=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{L}{g}}\)

Or \(g=L \times\left(\frac{2 \pi}{T}\right)^2\cdots(1)\)

Putting the given values in the equation number (1) we get:

\(g=0.5 L \times\left(\frac{2 \pi}{0.2 T}\right)^2\)

And we know that Relative Errors on multiplication and division get added and Relative Errors on exponential get multiplied.

Error in measuring length is \(\frac{\Delta l}{l}=0.5\)

Error in measuring time period is \(\frac{\Delta T}{T}=0.2\)

Then

\(\frac{\Delta g}{g}=\frac{\Delta l}{l}+\frac{2 \Delta T}{T} \)

\(=0.5+2 \times 0.2=0.9 \%\)

Thus the percentage error in the value of \(g\) is \(0.9 \%\)
In SI system the fundamental units are:
meter, kilogram, second, ampere, Kelvin, mole and candela
meter, kilogram, second, coulomb, Kelvin, mole and candela
meter, Newton, second, ampere, Kelvin, mole and candela
meter, kilogram, second, ampere, Kelvin, mole and lux

Fundamental quantities are those which cannot be expressed or measured in terms of other physical quantities.  The SI system has seven fundamental quantities i.e. length, mass, time, electric current, thermodynamic temperature, amount of substance, and luminous intensity and their units in SI system are meter, kilogram, second, ampere, Kelvin, mole, and candela respectively.
The quantity that does not have mass in its dimension is:

Dimension of electrical potential \(= [\mathrm{M^1 L^2 T^{-3} A^{-1}}]\)

Dimension of electrical resistance \(= [\mathrm{M^1 L^2 T^{-3} A^{-2}}]\)

Dimension of specific heat \(= [\mathrm{M^0 L^2 T^{-2}K^{-1}}]\)

Dimension of magnetic flux \(= [\mathrm{M^1 L^2 T^{-2}A^{-1}}]\)

So, the specific heat does not have mass in its dimension.
If \(\mathrm{M}\) denotes angular momentum and \(\mathrm{p}\) denotes linear momentum, the dimensions of \(\frac{\mathrm M}{\mathrm p}\) is:

Linear momentum is the measure of impact caused due to a moving object with mass. 

Linear momentum \(\mathrm{p=m v}\)

Where \(\mathrm m=\) mass and \(\mathrm v=\) is the velocity.

Angular momentum  is the rotational equivalent of linear momentum.

Angular momentum, \(\mathrm{M}=\mathrm{r} \times \mathrm{mv}\)

Where \(\mathrm m=\) mass, \(\mathrm r=\) radius and \(\mathrm v=\) velocity.

Ratio \(=\frac{\mathrm M}{\mathrm p}=\frac{\mathrm{r m v}}{\mathrm{m v}}=\mathrm r\)

The dimension of \(\mathrm{r =[L^1]}\)

So, the dimensions of \(\frac{\mathrm M}{\mathrm p}\) is \([\mathrm L^1]\).

The linear momentum of a body is the quantity of motion contained in the body. It is measured in terms of the force required to stop the body in unit time. It is also measured as the product of the mass of the body and its velocity i.e.,

Momentum \((p)=\) mass \((m) \times\) velocity \((v)\)

As we know that, the SI unit of mass is \(\mathrm{kg}\) and the SI unit of velocity is \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\). Therefore the unit of momentum is

\(p=\mathrm{kgms}^{-1}\)
What is the dimensional formula of strain?

The ratio of change in configuration to the original configuration is called strain.

Strain \(=\frac{\text { Change in dimension }}{\text { Original dimension }}\)

As the strain is the ratio of two like quantities, it has no units and no dimensions.

Its dimension can be express as \(\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}\).
Which of following is the dimensional formula of Density?

Density: It is defined as mass per unit volume.

i.e., Density \(=\frac{\text { Mass }}{\text { Volume }}\)

Now,

Dimensional formula of mass = [M]

Dimensional formula of volume \(=\left[\mathrm{L}^{3}\right]\)

Density \(=\frac{[M]}{\left[L^{3}\right]}\)

\(\Rightarrow\) Density \(=[\mathrm{ML}^{-3} \mathrm{~T}^{0}]\)

\(\therefore\) Dimensional formula of density is \(\left[\mathrm{ML}^{-3} \mathrm{~T}^{0}\right.\) ].
Which of the physics quantity has the same unit in both C.G.S and M.K.S system?

Time period (T): The time taken to complete one full oscillation or cycle by the Wave is called the time period.

  • The SI unit of the time period is second (sec).
  • The CGS unit of the time period is second (sec).

From the above, it is clear that time is the physics quantity that has the same unit in both C.G.S and the M.K.S system.
If \(x=a+b t+c t^{2}\), where \(x\) is in meters and \(t\) is in second. What is the unit of \(b\) and \(c\) ?

Given equation \(x=a+b t+c t^{2}\),

Here, units of \(x\) are meters.

Therefore by the law of homogeneity, units of \(x\) are the same as units of \(a\).

Units of \(a=\) Meter \((m)\)

Units of \(x=\) units of \(a=\) units of \(b t=\) units of \(c t^{2}\)

From above:

\(x=a=\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}\right] \)

\(x=\mathrm{bt} =\frac{x}{t}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{0}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{1}\right]}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]\)

Therefore units of \(b\) is \(\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\). Similarly,

\(x=\mathrm{ct}^{2} \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{c}=\frac{x}{t^{2}}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{L}^{0} \mathrm{T}^{0}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{M}^{0} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{2}\right]}=\left[\mathrm{M}^{1} \mathrm{~L}^{0} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)
The square root of the product of inductance and capacitance has the dimension of length:

Frequency is the number of oscillations or the number of waves passes a given point in one sec. 

\(\Rightarrow f=\frac{1}{T}\)

We know that the frequency of oscillations generated by the LC circuit entirely depends on the values of the capacitor and inductor and their resonance condition.

\(f=\frac{1}{2 \pi \sqrt{L C}}\)

Where \(L=\) Inductor and \(C\) = capacitor

From the above, it is clear that the resonant frequency can be written as

\(\Rightarrow f=\frac{1}{2 \pi \sqrt{L C}}\)

The above equation can be written as,

\( \Rightarrow \sqrt{L C}=\frac{1}{2 \pi f} \)

\(\Rightarrow \sqrt{L C}=\frac{T}{2 \pi}\)

Here, \(2 \pi\) is constant, therefore the dimension of \(\sqrt{L C}\) is

\(\Rightarrow \sqrt{L C}=\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]\)

So, the square root of the product of inductance and capacitance has the dimension of time.
Which one of the following is not a derived unit?

The work is the product of force and displacement.

\(W=F \times s\)

It can also be written as 

\(W=(m a) \times s=m \times \frac{v}{t} \times s=\frac{m s^{2}}{t^{2}}=m s^{2} t^{-2}\)

Substituting the fundamental units: mass, length and time.

\(\Rightarrow W=\left[M L^{2} T^{-2}\right]\)

Now,

The Watt is a unit of power. The power is the work done by time.

\(P=\frac{W}{t}\)

It can also be written as 

\(P=\frac{W}{t}=\frac{F \times s}{t}=\frac{(m a) \times s}{t}=\frac{m s}{t} \times \frac{v}{t}=\frac{m s^{2}}{t^{3}}=m s^{2} t^{-3}\)

Substitute the fundamental units: mass, length and time.

\(\Rightarrow P=\left[M L^{2} T^{-3}\right]\)

The Newton is a unit of force and force is the product of mass and acceleration.

\(F=m a\)

It can also be written as 

\(F=m a=m \times \frac{v}{t}=m \times \frac{s}{t} \times \frac{1}{t} =\frac{m s}{t^{2}}=m s t^{-2}\)

Now, we will substitute the fundamental units: mass, length and time.

\(\Rightarrow F=[M L T^{-2}]\)

Now consider, kilogram.

The dimensional formula of the kilogram is \(k g=[M]\)

So, Kilogram is not a derived unit.

Electric Dipole Moment \([=\mathrm{A L T}]\)

Potential Difference \(=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-3} \mathrm{~A}^{-1}\right]\)

Heat \(=\left[\mathrm{M} \mathrm{L}{ }^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right.\) ]

So only the pair of electric flux and electric dipole moment has a different dimensional formula for both quantities.

Given:

Measured value \(=25.34 \mathrm{~W}\)

Dimensional formula of \(\omega\) in equation \(y=a \sin (\omega t+k x)\) is:

Given \(y=a \sin (\omega t+k x)\)

As we know that the trigonometric function is a dimensionless quantity. So, (\(\omega{t}+{k x})\) is also a dimensionless quantity.

Here, \(t=\) time

The dimension of \({t}\) is given as,

\(\Rightarrow[t]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]\cdots(1)\)

Since the quantity \(\omega t\) is dimensionless.

\(\Rightarrow[\omega t]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^0\right]\cdots(2)\)

Let the dimension of \(\omega\) as,

\(\Rightarrow[\omega]=\left[M^x L^y T^z\right]\cdots(3)\)

By equation (1), equation (2) and equation (3),

\(\Rightarrow\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]\left[M^x L^y T^z\right]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^0\right] \)

\( \Rightarrow\left[M^x L^y T^{z+1}\right]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^0\right] \)

By comparison,

\(\Rightarrow x=0 \)

\( \Rightarrow y=0 \)

\(\Rightarrow z+1=0 \Rightarrow z=-1\)

So dimensional formula for \(\omega\) is,

\(\Rightarrow[\omega]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^{-1}\right]\)
Which of the following quantity has dimensional formula as that of \(\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Mass } \times \text { Length }}\) is:

Energy \(=\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{L}^2 \mathrm{T}^{-2}\right]\)

So the dimension of \(\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Mass } \times \text { Length }}\) is given as,

\(\Rightarrow\left[\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Mass } \times \text { Length }}\right]=\frac{\left[\mathrm{M^1 L^2 T^{-2}}\right]}{\left[\mathrm{M^1 L^1}\right]} =\left[\mathrm{M^0 L^1 T^{-2}}\right]\)

\(\Rightarrow[\mathrm{F}]=\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

The dimension of power is given as,

\(\Rightarrow[\mathrm{P}]=\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-3}\right]\)

The dimension of pressure is given as,

\(\Rightarrow[\mathrm{P}]=\left[\mathrm{M}^1 \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

The dimension of acceleration is given as,

\(\Rightarrow[\mathrm{a}]=\left[\mathrm{M}^0 \mathrm{~L}^1 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]\)

By the above explanation, it is clear that the dimensional formula for acceleration is the same as that of \(\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Mass } \times \text { Length }}\).

Which one of the following cannot be the unit of 'Pressure'?

Which of the following has the unit Candela?

\(\Rightarrow V^2=\left[M^2 L^4 T^{-6} A^{-2}\right] \)

\(C \cdot V^2  =\left[M^{-1} L^{-2} T^4 A^2\right]\times \left[M^2 L^4 T^{-6} A^{-2}\right]=\left[M L^2 T^{-2}\right]\)

If velocity \( v\), acceleration \(\mathrm A\) and force \(\mathrm F\) are chosen as fundamental quantities, then the dimensional formula of angular momentum in terms of \(v\) \(\mathrm A\) and \(\mathrm  F\) would be:

\( [\mathrm{F}]=\left[\mathrm{MLT}^{-2}\right]\)

\([{v}]=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right] \)

\([\mathrm{A}]=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-2}\right]\) 

and \([{\vec{L}]=\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-1}\right]}\)

If the speed of light (c), acceleration due to gravity ( \(g\) ) and pressure (p) are taken as the fundamental quantities, then the dimension of gravitational constant is:

Dimension of gravitational constant \(\mathrm{G}=\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^3 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\)

Gravity \({[\mathrm{g}]=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-2}\right]} \)

On equating dimensions

\({\left[\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^3 \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]=\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-1}\right]^\alpha\left[\mathrm{LT}^{-2}\right]^\beta\left[\mathrm{ML}^{-1} \mathrm{~T}^{-2}\right]^\gamma} \)

By comparison 

\(\gamma=-1\)

\(3=\alpha+\beta-\gamma =3 \)

\(\alpha+\beta=2\cdots (1) \)

And \(-\alpha-2 \beta-2 \gamma = -2\)

\(\alpha+2 \beta=4 \cdots (2)\)

Solving eq. (1) and (2) we get,

\(\alpha=0, \beta=2\)

\(\therefore\) Dimension \(=\mathrm{c}^{0} \mathrm{g}^2 \mathrm{p}^{-1}\)
If the time period \((T)\) of vibration of a liquid drop depends on surface tension ( \(S\) ), radius \((r)\) of the drop and density ( \(\rho\) ) of the liquid, then the expression of \(T\) is:

Dimensional formula of, Time period \([T]=\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]\)

Surface tension\([\mathrm{S}]=\left[\mathrm{ML}^{\circ} \mathrm{T}^{-2}\right]\)

Radius \([r]=\left[M^{\circ} L T^0\right]\)

Density \([\rho]=\left[M^1 L^{-3} T^0\right]\)

Let us suppose the relation is

\([T]=\left[k \rho^{\mathrm{a}} \mathrm{r}^{\mathrm{b}} \mathrm{S}^{\mathrm{c}}\right] \)

\(\Rightarrow\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]=\left[M^1 L^{-3} T^0\right]^a \times\left[M^0 L T^0\right]^b \times\left[M L^0 T^{-2}\right]^c \)

\( \Rightarrow\left[M^0 L^0 T^1\right]=\left[M^{(a+c)} L^{(-3 a+b)} T^{(-2 c)}\right] \)

On comparing, we get,

\(a+c=0 \cdots(i)\)

\(-3 a+b=0 \cdots(ii)\)

\(-2 c=1\cdots(iii)\)

On solving these equations, we get,

\(a=\frac{1}{2}, b=\frac{3}{2}\) and \(c =\frac{-1}{2}\)

Thus,

\(T=k \rho^a r^b S^c \Rightarrow T=k \sqrt{\rho r^3 / S}\)

We know that,

Electric Current \(I=\frac{q}{t}\)

or \(I=\frac{[Q]}{[T]}\)

Dimensional formula of electric current \(I=\left[M^0 L^0 T^{-1} Q\right]\)
The fundamental physical quantities that have same dimensions in the dimensional formulae of torque and angular momentum are:

Angular momentum \(=m v r=\frac{k g-m^2}{s}=[M L^2 T^{-1}]\)

Torque \(\tau=\) Force \(\times\) perpendicular distance \(=\frac{k g-m^2}{s^2}=[M L^2 T^{-2}]\)

Both have the same dimensional unit of mass \(M\) and length \(L\). So, The fundamental physical quantities that have same dimensions in the dimensional formulae of torque and angular momentum are mass and length.
If pressure \(P\), velocity \(v\) and time \(T\) are taken as fundamental physical quantities, the dimensional formula of force is:

\( F=P^\alpha v^\beta T^\gamma \)

or \(\left[M^1 L^1 T^{-2}\right]=\left[M^\alpha L^{-\alpha+\beta} T^{-2 \alpha-\beta+\gamma}\right] \)

i.e. \(\left[M^1 L^1 T^{-2}\right]=\left[M^\alpha L^{-\alpha+\beta} T^{-2 \alpha-\beta+\gamma}\right]\)

Hence we have,

\(\alpha=1,-\alpha+\beta=1 \text { and }-2 \alpha-\beta+\gamma=-2\)

Solving these we get,

\(\alpha=1, \beta=2, \gamma=2 \)

\(\Rightarrow F=Pv ^2 T^2\)

Luminous flux or Luminous power is an index of the perceived power of light.

\(J=\frac{\text { energy }}{\text { time }}\)

\(J=\frac{\left[M L^2 T^{-2}\right]}{[T]}\)

\(J=\left[M L^2 T^{-3}\right]\)
Which of the following represents the dimensions of Farad?

Farad is the unit of capacitance.

We know that

Capacitance \(=\frac{\text {Charge }}{\text { Voltage }}=\frac{I \times t}{\frac{\omega}{ q}} \) 

\(C=\frac{(I \times t) \times q}{\omega}=\frac{(I \times t)^2}{\omega} \)

\( C=\frac{[A T]^2}{\left[M L^2 T^{-2}\right]}=\left[M^{-1} L^{-2} T^4 A^2\right]\)
The dimensions of \(\mathrm{B}^2 \mathrm{~L}^2 \mathrm{C}\) (where \(\mathrm{B}\) is magnetic field, \(\mathrm{L}\) is length and \(\mathrm{C}\) is capacitance) is same as that of:

The dimension \(\mathrm{B}=\mathrm{MT}^{-2} \mathrm{~A}^{-1}\)

Dimension of \(\mathrm{C}=\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-2} \mathrm{~T}^4 \mathrm{A}^2\)

Dimension of \(\mathrm{L}=\mathrm{L}\)

\(\therefore \mathrm{B}^2 \mathrm{~L}^2 \mathrm{C}=[\mathrm{M}^2 \mathrm{~T}^{-4} \mathrm{~A}^{-2}] \times [\mathrm{~L}^2] \times [\mathrm{M}^{-1} \mathrm{~L}^{-2} \mathrm{~T}^4 \mathrm{~A}^2]  \)

\(=[\mathrm M \mathrm L^{0} \mathrm{T}^0 \mathrm{A}^0]=M =\) Dimension of Mass
The dimensional formula for strain is same as that for:

The strain is a dimensionless quantity because it is a ratio of two similar quantities, namely lengths, area or volume. 

The angle is considered to be a dimensionless physical quantity as it is measured in radians and thus is the ratio of two lengths. So, the angle has the same dimensional formula as strain because both of them are dimensionless.
Dimensions of velocity gradient are same as that of:

The dimension of velocity gradient is given by

\(\frac{\text { Dimension of Velocity }}{\text { Dimension of Distance }}=\frac{\left[L T^{-1}\right]}{[L]}=\left[T^{-1}\right]\)

The time period is the time taken to complete one cycle of operations so the dimension of the time period is [T].

Frequency is the number of cycles per second, frequency is measured in Hertz and the dimension is given by

\(\Rightarrow \nu=\frac{1}{\text { Dimension of time }}=\frac{1}{[T]}=[T]^{-1}\)

The dimension of the velocity gradient is the same as that of frequency.

The unit of the Capacitance is Farad.

Since, temperature is the fundamental quantity, so, it can not be derived from any other physical quantity.
Which of the following is a dimensionless quantity?

A dimensionless quantity is the one for which no physical dimension is assigned. It is also known as a bare, pure, or scalar quantity or also as a quantity of dimension one.

Work and energy both are having the same dimensions as \(\left[\mathrm{ML}^2 \mathrm{~T}^2\right]\). 

The ratio \(\frac{\text { Energy }}{\text { Work }}\) will be a dimensionless quantity.
Which of the following is a dimensional constant?

Refractive Index is defined as the relative speed at which light moves through a material with respect to its speed in vacuum. As both the values belong to the same quantity (speed), units get nullified.So the Refractive Index is a dimensionless quantity.

If \(C\) is the value of the capacitance of a capacitor filled with a given dielectric and \(C_0\) is the capacitance of an identical capacitor in a vacuum, the dielectric constant, symbolized by the Greek letter kappa, \(\kappa\), is simply expressed as :

\(\kappa=C / C_0\)

The dielectric constant is a number without dimensions.

Relative density of a substance is defined as the density of a substance divided by the density of water. So, it is a pure ratio and has no dimensions. Therefore, relative density is dimensionless.

A gravitational coupling constant is a constant characterizing the gravitational attraction between a given pair of elementary particles. Therefore, the dimension of the gravitational constant is \([M^{-1} L^3 T^{-2}]\).
